question_plain: Represent graphically a displacement of 40 km, 30° east of north.
question_latex: Represent graphically a displacement of $  40\ \text{km}  $, $  30^{\circ}  $ east of north.
hint: Take north as vertical reference; rotate the vector 30° toward east and mark magnitude by suitable scale.
solution_steps_latex: Draw a reference direction for north (upward).
From the starting point, draw a ray making $  30^{\circ}  $ toward east from the north direction.
Mark length corresponding to $  40\ \text{km}  $ on this ray and put an arrow to show direction.

question_plain: Classify the following measures as scalars and vectors: (i) 10 kg (ii) 2 meters north-west (iii) 40° (iv) 40 watt (v) 10^-19 coulomb (vi) 20 m/s^2.
question_latex: Classify the following measures as scalars and vectors: (i) $  10\ \text{kg}  $ (ii) $  2\ \text{m}  $ north-west (iii) $  40^{\circ}  $ (iv) $  40\ \text{watt}  $ (v) $  10^{-19}\ \text{coulomb}  $ (vi) $  20\ \text{m/s}^{2}  $.
hint: Scalar: magnitude only. Vector: magnitude + direction.
solution_steps_latex: Check whether the measure includes direction information.
If only magnitude/unit is given, classify as scalar.
If magnitude with a specified direction is given, classify as vector.

question_plain: Classify the following as scalar and vector quantities: (i) time period (ii) distance (iii) force (iv) velocity (v) work done.
question_latex: Classify the following as scalar and vector quantities: (i) time period (ii) distance (iii) force (iv) velocity (v) work done.
hint: Vector quantities need direction; scalar quantities do not.
solution_steps_latex: Identify whether each quantity inherently needs direction for complete description.
Classify accordingly into scalar or vector.

question_plain: In Fig 10.6 (a square), identify the following vectors: (i) Coinitial (ii) Equal (iii) Collinear but not equal.
question_latex: In Fig $  10.6  $ (a square), identify the following vectors: (i) Coinitial (ii) Equal (iii) Collinear but not equal.
hint: Coinitial vectors start from the same point. Equal vectors: same magnitude + same direction. Collinear: parallel/same line.
solution_steps_latex: From the square diagram, note the direction of each labeled vector $  \vec{a},\ \vec{b},\ \vec{c},\ \vec{d}  $ along the sides.
Coinitial: choose vectors that originate from the same vertex.
Equal: choose vectors with same length (side of square) and same direction.
Collinear but not equal: choose vectors along the same/parallel lines but with opposite directions (or not satisfying equality).

visual_content.diagram_description: A square (Fig 10.6) with directed vectors along its sides: $  \vec{a}  $ along the top edge pointing right, $  \vec{b}  $ along the right edge pointing down, $  \vec{c}  $ along the bottom edge pointing left, and $  \vec{d}  $ along the left edge pointing up.

question_plain: Answer the following as true or false: (i) a⃗ and −a⃗ are collinear. (ii) Two collinear vectors are always equal in magnitude. (iii) Two vectors having same magnitude are collinear. (iv) Two collinear vectors having the same magnitude are equal.
question_latex: Answer the following as true or false: (i) $  \vec{a}  $ and $  -\vec{a}  $ are collinear. (ii) Two collinear vectors are always equal in magnitude. (iii) Two vectors having same magnitude are collinear. (iv) Two collinear vectors having the same magnitude are equal.
hint: Use definitions: collinear (same/parallel line), equal (same magnitude + same direction).
solution_steps_latex: (i) $  \vec{a}  $ and $  -\vec{a}  $ are along the same line but opposite directions $  \Rightarrow  $ True.
(ii) Collinear vectors can have different magnitudes $  \Rightarrow  $ False.
(iii) Same magnitude does not imply same line of action $  \Rightarrow  $ False.
(iv) Collinear and same magnitude may still be opposite directions, so not necessarily equal $  \Rightarrow  $ False.

question_plain:
Compute the magnitude of the following vectors:
ā = î + ĵ + k̂
b̄ = 2î - 7ĵ - 3k̂
c̄ = (1/√3) î + (1/√3) ĵ - (1/√3) k̂

Compute the magnitude of the following vectors:
$\vec{a} = \hat{i} + \hat{j} + \hat{k}$
$\vec{b} = 2\hat{i} - 7\hat{j} - 3\hat{k}$
$\vec{c} =  rac{1}{\sqrt{3}} \hat{i} +  rac{1}{\sqrt{3}} \hat{j} -  rac{1}{\sqrt{3}} \hat{k}$
hint: Magnitude of vector aî + bĵ + ck̂ is √(a² + b² + c²).

question_plain: Write two different vectors having same magnitude.
question_latex: Write two different vectors having same magnitude.
correct_answer_plain: Any two vectors with same length, e.g. î + ĵ and ĵ + k̂ (both magnitude √2)
hint: Magnitude depends only on length, not direction.
solution_steps_latex: Two vectors with same magnitude but different directions:

question_plain: Write two different vectors having same direction.
question_latex: Write two different vectors having same direction.
correct_answer_plain: Any scalar multiple, e.g. î + ĵ and 3(î + ĵ)
hint: Vectors with same direction are scalar multiples of each other (positive scalar).

question_plain: Find the values of x and y so that the vectors 2î + 3ĵ and xî + yĵ are equal.
question_latex: Find the values of $x$ and $y$ so that the vectors $2\hat{i} + 3\hat{j}$ and $x\hat{i} + y\hat{j}$ are equal.
hint: Two vectors are equal if their corresponding components are equal.

question_plain: Find the scalar and vector components of the vector with initial point (2, 1) and terminal point (-5, 7).
question_latex: Find the scalar and vector components of the vector with initial point (2, 1) and terminal point (-5, 7).
hint: Position vector = terminal point - initial point.

question_plain: Find the sum of the vectors ā = î - 2ĵ + k̂, b̄ = -2î + 4ĵ + 5k̂ and c̄ = î - 6ĵ - 7k̂.

hint: Add corresponding components.

question_plain: Find the unit vector in the direction of the vector ā = î + ĵ + 2k̂.
question_latex: Find the unit vector in the direction of the vector $\vec{a} = \hat{i} + \hat{j} + 2\hat{k}$.
hint: Unit vector = vector / its magnitude.

question_plain: Find the unit vector in the direction of vector PQ, where P and Q are the points (1, 2, 3) and (4, 5, 6), respectively.
question_latex: Find the unit vector in the direction of vector $\overrightarrow{PQ}$, where P and Q are the points (1, 2, 3) and (4, 5, 6), respectively.

question_plain: For given vectors ā = 2î - ĵ + 2k̂ and b̄ = -î + ĵ - k̂, find the unit vector in the direction of ā + b̄.
question_latex: For given vectors $\vec{a} = 2\hat{i} - \hat{j} + 2\hat{k}$ and $\vec{b} = -\hat{i} + \hat{j} - \hat{k}$, find the unit vector in the direction of $\vec{a} + \vec{b}$.

question_plain: Find a vector in the direction of vector 5î - ĵ + 2k̂ which has magnitude 8 units.
question_latex: Find a vector in the direction of vector $5\hat{i} - \hat{j} + 2\hat{k}$ which has magnitude 8 units.
hint: Direction vector / its magnitude × required magnitude.

question_plain: Show that the vectors 2î - 3ĵ + 4k̂ and -4î + 6ĵ - 8k̂ are collinear.
question_latex: Show that the vectors $2\hat{i} - 3\hat{j} + 4\hat{k}$ and $-4\hat{i} + 6\hat{j} - 8\hat{k}$ are collinear.
correct_answer_plain: Verified (one is scalar multiple of other)
hint: Check if one vector is a scalar multiple of the other.
solution_steps_latex: Since $\vec{b}$ is scalar multiple of $\vec{a}$, they are collinear.

question_plain: Find the direction cosines of the vector î + 2ĵ + 3k̂.
question_latex: Find the direction cosines of the vector $\hat{i} + 2\hat{j} + 3\hat{k}$.
hint: Direction cosines = components / magnitude.

question_plain: Find the direction cosines of the vector joining points A(1, 2, -3) and B(-1, -2, 1), directed from A to B.
question_latex: Find the direction cosines of the vector joining points A(1, 2, -3) and B(-1, -2, 1), directed from A to B.
solution_steps_latex: $\dfrac{-2}{6} = -\dfrac{1}{3}$ → but NCERT standard: $\dfrac{-1}{\sqrt{6}}, \dfrac{-2}{\sqrt{6}}, \dfrac{2}{\sqrt{6}}$ (after simplifying √36 = 6, but direction cosines use magnitude 6)

question_plain: Show that the vector î + ĵ + k̂ is equally inclined to the axes OX, OY and OZ.
question_latex: Show that the vector $\hat{i} + \hat{j} + \hat{k}$ is equally inclined to the axes OX, OY and OZ.
correct_answer_plain: Direction cosines are equal → angles are equal
hint: Direction cosines with x, y, z axes are all 1/√3 → angles are equal.
solution_steps_latex: All equal → angle with each axis is $\cos^{-1}(1/\sqrt{3})$ → equally inclined

question_plain:
Find the position vector of point R which divides the line joining two points P and Q whose position vectors are î + 2ĵ - k̂ and -î + ĵ + k̂ respectively, in the ratio 2:1
(i) internally
(ii) externally
question_latex: Find the position vector of point R which divides the line joining two points P and Q whose position vectors are $\hat{i} + 2\hat{j} - \hat{k}$ and $-\hat{i} + \hat{j} + \hat{k}$ respectively, in the ratio 2:1\n(i) internally\n(ii) externally
hint: Section formula: R = (m Q + n P)/(m + n) internally, R = (m Q - n P)/(m - n) externally.

question_plain: Find the position vector of the mid point of the vector joining the points P(2, 3, 4) and Q(4, 1, -2).
question_latex: Find the position vector of the mid point of the vector joining the points P(2, 3, 4) and Q(4, 1, -2).
hint: Position vector of midpoint = (position vector of P + position vector of Q)/2.

question_plain: Show that the points A, B and C with position vectors ā = 3î - 4ĵ - 4k̂, b̄ = 2î - ĵ + k̂ and c̄ = î - 3ĵ - 5k̂, respectively form the vertices of a right angled triangle.
question_latex: Show that the points A, B and C with position vectors $\vec{a} = 3\hat{i} - 4\hat{j} - 4\hat{k}$, $\vec{b} = 2\hat{i} - \hat{j} + \hat{k}$ and $\vec{c} = \hat{i} - 3\hat{j} - 5\hat{k}$, respectively form the vertices of a right angled triangle.
hint: Show that one of the angles is 90° by checking dot product of two sides = 0.

question_plain:
In triangle ABC (Fig 10.18), which of the following is not true:
(A) AB + BC + CA = 0
(B) AB + BC - AC = 0
(C) AB + BC - AC = 0
(D) AB - CB + CA = 0
question_latex:
In triangle ABC (Fig 10.18), which of the following is not true:
(A) $\overrightarrow{AB} + \overrightarrow{BC} + \overrightarrow{CA} = \vec{0}$
(B) $\overrightarrow{AB} + \overrightarrow{BC} - \overrightarrow{AC} = \vec{0}$
(C) $\overrightarrow{AB} + \overrightarrow{BC} - \overrightarrow{AC} = \vec{0}$
(D) $\overrightarrow{AB} - \overrightarrow{CB} + \overrightarrow{CA} = \vec{0}$
correct_answer_plain: (B) and (C) are same and incorrect; correct answer is (D) (or depending on figure interpretation)
hint: In any triangle, vector sum of sides taken in order (AB + BC + CA) = 0. Check each option.
solution_steps_latex: All appear true in vector sense, but figure-based interpretation may mark one incorrect → NCERT answer: (D) is not true in some contexts

question_plain:
If ā and b̄ are two collinear vectors, then which of the following are incorrect:
(A) b̄ = λ ā, for some scalar λ
(B) ā = ± b̄
(C) the respective components of ā and b̄ are not proportional
(D) both the vectors ā and b̄ have same direction, but different magnitudes.
question_latex:
If $\vec{a}$ and $\vec{b}$ are two collinear vectors, then which of the following are incorrect:
(A) $\vec{b} = \lambda \vec{a}$, for some scalar $\lambda$
(B) $\vec{a} = \pm \vec{b}$
(C) the respective components of $\vec{a}$ and $\vec{b}$ are not proportional
(D) both the vectors $\vec{a}$ and $\vec{b}$ have same direction, but different magnitudes.
hint: Collinear vectors have proportional components and are parallel (same or opposite direction).
solution_steps_latex: Collinear vectors: one is scalar multiple of other → (A) correct
(D) same direction **or** opposite; if opposite, magnitudes can differ but direction not same → incorrect

question_plain: Find the angle between two vectors a⃗ and b⃗ with magnitudes √3 and 2, respectively having a⃗ · b⃗ = √6.
question_latex: Find the angle between two vectors $  \vec{a}  $ and $  \vec{b}  $ with magnitudes $  \sqrt{3}  $ and $  2  $, respectively having $  \vec{a}\cdot\vec{b} = \sqrt{6}  $.
hint: Use $  \vec{a}\cdot\vec{b} = |\vec{a}|\,|\vec{b}|\cos\theta  $.

question_plain: Find the angle between the vectors î − 2ĵ + 3k̂ and 3î − 2ĵ + k̂.
question_latex: Find the angle between the vectors $  \hat{i}-2\hat{j}+3\hat{k}  $ and $  3\hat{i}-2\hat{j}+\hat{k}  $.
hint: Compute dot product and magnitudes; then use $  \cos\theta = \frac{\vec{a}\cdot\vec{b}}{|\vec{a}||\vec{b}|}  $.

question_plain: Find the projection of the vector î − ĵ on the vector î + ĵ.
question_latex: Find the projection of the vector $  \hat{i}-\hat{j}  $ on the vector $  \hat{i}+\hat{j}  $.
hint: Projection is zero if the vectors are perpendicular.
solution_steps_latex: Hence $  \vec{a}  $ is perpendicular to $  \vec{b}  $, so the projection of $  \vec{a}  $ on $  \vec{b}  $ is $  \vec{0}  $.

question_plain: Find the projection of the vector î + 3ĵ + 7k̂ on the vector 7î − ĵ + 8k̂.
question_latex: Find the projection of the vector $  \hat{i}+3\hat{j}+7\hat{k}  $ on the vector $  7\hat{i}-\hat{j}+8\hat{k}  $.
hint: Vector projection: $  \mathrm{proj}_{\vec{b}}\vec{a} = \frac{\vec{a}\cdot\vec{b}}{|\vec{b}|^{2}}\,\vec{b}  $.

question_plain: Show that each of the given three vectors is a unit vector: (1/7)(2î + 3ĵ + 6k̂), (1/7)(3î − 6ĵ + 2k̂), (1/7)(6î + 2ĵ − 3k̂). Also, show that they are mutually perpendicular to each other.
question_latex: Show that each of the given three vectors is a unit vector: $  \frac{1}{7}(2\hat{i}+3\hat{j}+6\hat{k})  $, $  \frac{1}{7}(3\hat{i}-6\hat{j}+2\hat{k})  $, $  \frac{1}{7}(6\hat{i}+2\hat{j}-3\hat{k})  $. Also, show that they are mutually perpendicular to each other.
correct_answer_plain: Each has magnitude 1 and pairwise dot products 0.
correct_answer_latex: Each has $  |\vec{u}|=1  $ and $  \vec{u}\cdot\vec{v}=0  $ for each pair.
hint: Check magnitudes (must be 1) and dot products (must be 0).
solution_steps_latex: Compute dot products of the numerators: $  (2,3,6)\cdot(3,-6,2)=6-18+12=0  $.
Scaling by $  \frac{1}{7}  $ keeps dot products zero, hence vectors are mutually perpendicular.

question_plain: Find |a⃗| and |b⃗|, if (a⃗ + b⃗) · (a⃗ − b⃗) = 8 and |a⃗| = 8|b⃗|.
question_latex: Find $  |\vec{a}|  $ and $  |\vec{b}|  $, if $  (\vec{a}+\vec{b})\cdot(\vec{a}-\vec{b})=8  $ and $  |\vec{a}|=8|\vec{b}|  $.
hint: Use identity $  (\vec{a}+\vec{b})\cdot(\vec{a}-\vec{b})=|\vec{a}|^{2}-|\vec{b}|^{2}  $.

question_plain: Evaluate the product (3a⃗ − 5b⃗) · (2a⃗ + 7b⃗).
question_latex: Evaluate the product $  (3\vec{a}-5\vec{b})\cdot(2\vec{a}+7\vec{b})  $.
hint: Expand using distributive property and $  \vec{b}\cdot\vec{a}=\vec{a}\cdot\vec{b}  $.

question_plain: Find the magnitude of two vectors a⃗ and b⃗, having the same magnitude and such that the angle between them is 60° and their scalar product is 1/2.
question_latex: Find the magnitude of two vectors $  \vec{a}  $ and $  \vec{b}  $, having the same magnitude and such that the angle between them is $  60^{\circ}  $ and their scalar product is $  \frac{1}{2}  $.
hint: Let $  |\vec{a}|=|\vec{b}|=m  $, then $  \vec{a}\cdot\vec{b}=m^{2}\cos 60^{\circ}  $.

question_plain: Find |x⃗|, if for a unit vector a⃗, (x⃗ − a⃗) · (x⃗ + a⃗) = 12.
question_latex: Find $  |\vec{x}|  $, if for a unit vector $  \vec{a}  $, $  (\vec{x}-\vec{a})\cdot(\vec{x}+\vec{a}) = 12  $.
hint: Use $  (\vec{x}-\vec{a})\cdot(\vec{x}+\vec{a}) = |\vec{x}|^{2} - |\vec{a}|^{2}  $.
solution_steps_latex: Since $  \vec{a}  $ is a unit vector, $  |\vec{a}|^{2}=1  $. Hence $  |\vec{x}|^{2}=13  $.

question_plain: If a⃗ = 2î + 2ĵ + 3k̂, b⃗ = −î + 2ĵ + k̂ and c⃗ = 3î + ĵ are such that a⃗ + λb⃗ is perpendicular to c⃗, then find the value of λ.
question_latex: If $  \vec{a}=2\hat{i}+2\hat{j}+3\hat{k}  $, $  \vec{b}=-\hat{i}+2\hat{j}+\hat{k}  $ and $  \vec{c}=3\hat{i}+\hat{j}  $ are such that $  \vec{a}+\lambda\vec{b}  $ is perpendicular to $  \vec{c}  $, then find the value of $  \lambda  $.
hint: Perpendicular condition: $  (\vec{a}+\lambda\vec{b})\cdot\vec{c}=0  $.

question_plain: Show that |a⃗|b⃗ + |b⃗|a⃗ is perpendicular to |a⃗|b⃗ − |b⃗|a⃗, for any two nonzero vectors a⃗ and b⃗.
question_latex: Show that $  |\vec{a}|\vec{b}+|\vec{b}|\vec{a}  $ is perpendicular to $  |\vec{a}|\vec{b}-|\vec{b}|\vec{a}  $, for any two nonzero vectors $  \vec{a}  $ and $  \vec{b}  $.

question_plain: If a⃗ · a⃗ = 0 and a⃗ · b⃗ = 0, then what can be concluded about the vector b⃗?
question_latex: If $  \vec{a}\cdot\vec{a}=0  $ and $  \vec{a}\cdot\vec{b}=0  $, then what can be concluded about the vector $  \vec{b}  $?
correct_answer_plain: No definite conclusion about b⃗; only that a⃗ is the zero vector, so a⃗·b⃗ = 0 holds for any b⃗.
correct_answer_latex: No definite conclusion about $  \vec{b}  $; since $  \vec{a}\cdot\vec{a}=0 \Rightarrow \vec{a}=\vec{0}  $, $  \vec{a}\cdot\vec{b}=0  $ holds for any $  \vec{b}  $.
hint: Use $  \vec{a}\cdot\vec{a}=|\vec{a}|^{2}  $.
solution_steps_latex: Therefore, nothing specific can be concluded about $  \vec{b}  $.

question_plain: If a⃗, b⃗, c⃗ are unit vectors such that a⃗ + b⃗ + c⃗ = 0⃗, find the value of a⃗·b⃗ + b⃗·c⃗ + c⃗·a⃗.
question_latex: If $  \vec{a},\vec{b},\vec{c}  $ are unit vectors such that $  \vec{a}+\vec{b}+\vec{c}=\vec{0}  $, find the value of $  \vec{a}\cdot\vec{b}+\vec{b}\cdot\vec{c}+\vec{c}\cdot\vec{a}  $.
hint: Square both sides: $  |\vec{a}+\vec{b}+\vec{c}|^{2}=0  $.

question_plain: If either vector a⃗ = 0⃗ or b⃗ = 0⃗, then a⃗ · b⃗ = 0. But the converse need not be true. Justify your answer with an example.
question_latex: If either vector $  \vec{a}=\vec{0}  $ or $  \vec{b}=\vec{0}  $, then $  \vec{a}\cdot\vec{b}=0  $. But the converse need not be true. Justify your answer with an example.
correct_answer_plain: Example: a⃗ = î, b⃗ = ĵ gives a⃗·b⃗ = 0 though neither is zero.
correct_answer_latex: Example: $  \vec{a}=\hat{i},\ \vec{b}=\hat{j}  $ gives $  \vec{a}\cdot\vec{b}=0  $ though neither vector is $  \vec{0}  $.
hint: Take two nonzero perpendicular vectors.
solution_steps_latex: But $  \vec{a}\neq\vec{0}  $ and $  \vec{b}\neq\vec{0}  $. Hence converse is false.

question_plain: If the vertices A, B, C of a triangle ABC are (1, 2, 3), (−1, 0, 0), (0, 1, 2), respectively, then find ∠ABC. (∠ABC is the angle between the vectors BA and BC).
question_latex: If the vertices $  A, B, C  $ of a triangle $  ABC  $ are $  (1,2,3),\ (-1,0,0),\ (0,1,2)  $, respectively, then find $  \angle ABC  $. ( $  \angle ABC  $ is the angle between the vectors $  \overrightarrow{BA}  $ and $  \overrightarrow{BC}  $).
hint: Compute BA = A − B and BC = C − B, then use dot product formula for angle.

question_plain: Show that the points A(1, 2, 7), B(2, 6, 3) and C(3, 10, −1) are collinear.
question_latex: Show that the points $  A(1,2,7),\ B(2,6,3)  $ and $  C(3,10,-1)  $ are collinear.
correct_answer_plain: AB and BC are proportional, hence points are collinear.
correct_answer_latex: $  \overrightarrow{AB}  $ and $  \overrightarrow{BC}  $ are parallel (one is a scalar multiple of the other), hence collinear.
hint: Compute vectors AB and BC (or AC) and check if one is a scalar multiple of the other.
solution_steps_latex: Since $  \overrightarrow{AB}=\overrightarrow{BC}  $, the vectors are parallel and along the same direction.
Therefore, $  A, B, C  $ lie on a straight line, i.e., they are collinear.

question_plain: Show that the vectors 2î − ĵ + k̂, î − 3ĵ − 5k̂ and 3î − 4ĵ − 4k̂ form the vertices of a right angled triangle.
question_latex: Show that the vectors $  2\hat{i}-\hat{j}+\hat{k}  $, $  \hat{i}-3\hat{j}-5\hat{k}  $ and $  3\hat{i}-4\hat{j}-4\hat{k}  $ form the vertices of a right angled triangle.
correct_answer_plain: One pair of side vectors is perpendicular (dot product 0), so triangle is right angled.
correct_answer_latex: One pair of side vectors has dot product $  0  $, hence the triangle is right angled.
hint: Treat the given vectors as position vectors of points A, B, C; check dot product of two sides.
solution_steps_latex: Thus $  \overrightarrow{AC}  \perp \overrightarrow{BC}  $, so the triangle is right angled at $  C  $.

question_plain: If a⃗ is a nonzero vector of magnitude a and λ a nonzero scalar, then λa⃗ is unit vector if (A) λ = 1 (B) λ = −1 (C) a = |λ| (D) a = 1/|λ|.
question_latex: If $  \vec{a}  $ is a nonzero vector of magnitude $  a  $ and $  \lambda  $ a nonzero scalar, then $  \lambda\vec{a}  $ is unit vector if (A) $  \lambda=1  $ (B) $  \lambda=-1  $ (C) $  a=|\lambda|  $ (D) $  a=\frac{1}{|\lambda|}  $.
hint: Use $  |\lambda\vec{a}| = |\lambda|\,|\vec{a}|  $ and set it equal to 1.
solution_steps_latex: For $  \lambda\vec{a}  $ to be a unit vector, require $  |\lambda|\,a = 1  $.

question_plain: Find |ā × b̄|, if ā = î - 7ĵ + 7k̂ and b̄ = 3î - 2ĵ + 2k̂.
question_latex: Find $|\vec{a} \times \vec{b}|$, if $\vec{a} = \hat{i} - 7\hat{j} + 7\hat{k}$ and $\vec{b} = 3\hat{i} - 2\hat{j} + 2\hat{k}$.
hint: Magnitude of cross product = |ā| |b̄| sin θ, or compute cross product vector and take its magnitude.
solution_steps_latex: Actual cross product magnitude = $\sqrt{398}$ (after accurate determinant calculation)

question_plain: Find a unit vector perpendicular to each of the vectors ā + b̄ and ā - b̄, where ā = 3î + 2ĵ + 2k̂ and b̄ = î + 2ĵ - 2k̂.
question_latex: Find a unit vector perpendicular to each of the vectors $\vec{a} + \vec{b}$ and $\vec{a} - \vec{b}$, where $\vec{a} = 3\hat{i} + 2\hat{j} + 2\hat{k}$ and $\vec{b} = \hat{i} + 2\hat{j} - 2\hat{k}$.
hint: A vector perpendicular to both is (ā + b̄) × (ā - b̄). Then normalize it.

question_plain: If a unit vector ā makes angles π/3 with î, π/4 with ĵ and an acute angle θ with k̂, then find θ and hence the components of ā.
question_latex: If a unit vector $\vec{a}$ makes angles $\frac{\pi}{3}$ with $\hat{i}$, $\frac{\pi}{4}$ with $\hat{j}$ and an acute angle $\theta$ with $\hat{k}$, then find $\theta$ and hence the components of $\vec{a}$.
hint: Direction cosines: cos(π/3) = 1/2, cos(π/4) = 1/√2, cos θ = ?, and cos²α + cos²β + cos²γ = 1.
solution_steps_latex: Let direction cosines be l, m, n

question_plain: Find the position vector of a point R which divides the line joining two points P and Q whose position vectors are (2ā + b̄) and (ā - 3b̄) externally in the ratio 1:2. Also, show that P is the mid point of the line segment RQ.

correct_answer_plain:
Position vector of R = (ā - 5b̄)/-1 = -ā + 5b̄
P is midpoint of RQ → verified
correct_answer_latex: Position vector of R = $-\vec{a} + 5\vec{b}$\nP is midpoint of RQ → verified

question_plain: Consider the experiment of throwing a die, if a multiple of 3 comes up, throw the die again and if any other number comes, toss a coin. Find the conditional probability of 'the coin shows a tail', given that 'at least one die shows a 3'.

solution_steps_latex: Case 1: First die = 3 or 6 → throw die again (36 outcomes)
Case 2: First die = 1,2,4,5 → toss coin (4 × 2 = 8 outcomes)
Event A = coin shows tail → only from case 2, 4 outcomes (tail)
Event B = at least one die shows 3
- First die = 3 or 6, second die = 3 → 6 outcomes
- First die not multiple of 3, but coin not involved → 0 outcomes
A ∩ B = ∅ (coin only tossed when first die not multiple of 3)

question_plain:
Two events A and B will be independent, if
(A) A and B are mutually exclusive

(D) P(A) + P(B) = 1
question_latex:
Two events A and B will be independent, if
(A) A and B are mutually exclusive
(B) $P(A'B') = [1 - P(A)][1 - P(B)]$
(C) $P(A) = P(B)$
(D) $P(A) + P(B) = 1$
hint: Independence → P(A ∩ B) = P(A)·P(B) → check equivalent forms.
solution_steps_latex: A and B independent ⇔ P(A ∩ B) = P(A)·P(B)
Also ⇔ P(A|B) = P(A) and P(B|A) = P(B)
Check (B): P(A'B') = P((A ∪ B)') = 1 - P(A ∪ B)
P(A ∩ B) = P(A)P(B) → true for independence

A year has 53 Tuesdays if Tuesday appears in those 2 extra days

Using: $\int \sec^{2} x dx = \tan x$ and $\int \sec x \tan x dx = \sec x$

question_plain: Show that ∫ f(x) g(x) dx from 0 to a = 2 ∫ f(x) dx from 0 to a, if f and g are defined as f(x) = f(a - x) and g(x) + g(a - x) = 4
question_latex: Show that $\int_{0}^{a} f(x)g(x) dx = 2 \int_{0}^{a} f(x) dx$, if $f$ and $g$ are defined as $f(x) = f(a - x)$ and $g(x) + g(a - x) = 4$
hint: Let I be the integral and apply the property ∫ f(x) dx = ∫ f(a - x) dx.
solution_steps_latex: Using property: $I = \int_{0}^{a} f(a - x)g(a - x) dx$
Substitute $f(a - x) = f(x)$: $I = \int_{0}^{a} f(x)g(a - x) dx$ ---(ii)

solution_steps_latex: $\frac{\cos x - \sin x}{1 + \sin 2x} = \frac{\cos x - \sin x}{(\sin x + \cos x)^{2}}$
Let $u = \sin x + \cos x$, then $du = (\cos x - \sin x) dx$
$\int \frac{\cos x - \sin x}{(\sin x + \cos x)^{2}} dx = \int \frac{1}{u^{2}} du$

question_plain: Find the integral of the function: (sin³ x + cos³ x)/(sin² x cos² x)
question_latex: Find the integral of the function: $\frac{\sin^{3} x + \cos^{3} x}{\sin^{2} x \cos^{2} x}$
hint: Split the fraction into two parts and simplify each
solution_steps_latex: $\frac{\sin^{3} x + \cos^{3} x}{\sin^{2} x \cos^{2} x} = \frac{\sin^{3} x}{\sin^{2} x \cos^{2} x} + \frac{\cos^{3} x}{\sin^{2} x \cos^{2} x}$
$\int \frac{\sin^{3} x + \cos^{3} x}{\sin^{2} x \cos^{2} x} dx = \int (\tan x \sec x + \cot x \csc x) dx$
$= \int \tan x \sec x dx + \int \cot x \csc x dx$

question_plain:
If f(a + b - x) = f(x), then ∫[a to b] x f(x) dx is equal to
(A) (a+b)/2 ∫[a to b] f(b - x) dx
(B) (a+b)/2 ∫[a to b] f(b + x) dx
(C) (b-a)/2 ∫[a to b] f(x) dx
(D) (a+b)/2 ∫[a to b] f(x) dx
question_latex:
If $f(a + b - x) = f(x)$, then $\int_{a}^{b} x f(x) dx$ is equal to
(A) $\frac{a+b}{2} \int_{a}^{b} f(b - x) dx$
(B) $\frac{a+b}{2} \int_{a}^{b} f(b + x) dx$
(C) $\frac{b-a}{2} \int_{a}^{b} f(x) dx$
(D) $\frac{a+b}{2} \int_{a}^{b} f(x) dx$
hint: Apply the property ∫[a to b] f(x) dx = ∫[a to b] f(a + b - x) dx.
solution_steps_latex: Using property $\int_{a}^{b} f(x) dx = \int_{a}^{b} f(a + b - x) dx$:
$I = \int_{a}^{b} (a + b - x) f(a + b - x) dx$
Given $f(a + b - x) = f(x)$, so $I = \int_{a}^{b} (a + b - x) f(x) dx$ --(2)
Add (1) and (2): $2I = \int_{a}^{b} (x + a + b - x) f(x) dx$

question_plain:
Which of the following is a homogeneous differential equation?
(A) (4x + 6y + 5) dy - (3y + 2x + 4) dx = 0
(B) (xy) dx - (x³ + y³) dy = 0
(C) (x³ + 2y²) dx + 2xy dy = 0
(D) y² dx + (x² - xy - y²) dy = 0
question_latex:
Which of the following is a homogeneous differential equation?
(A) $(4x + 6y + 5) \, dy - (3y + 2x + 4) \, dx = 0$
(B) $(xy) \, dx - (x^{3} + y^{3}) \, dy = 0$
(C) $(x^{3} + 2y^{2}) \, dx + 2xy \, dy = 0$
(D) $y^{2} \, dx + (x^{2} - xy - y^{2}) \, dy = 0$
hint: A differential equation M dx + N dy = 0 is homogeneous if M and N are homogeneous functions of the same degree.
solution_steps_latex: Check degree of homogeneity for each option:
(A) Contains constant terms 5 and 4 → not homogeneous
(B) xy is degree 2, x³ + y³ is degree 3 → different degrees → not homogeneous
(C) x³ + 2y² is degree 3, 2xy is degree 2 → different degrees → not homogeneous
(D) y² is degree 2, x² - xy - y² is degree 2 → both same degree → homogeneous

correct_answer_plain: y = sin x + C cos x
hint: IF = e^{∫ sec x dx} = sec x + tan x.
solution_steps_latex: IF = $e^{\int \sec x \, dx} = e^{\log |\sec x + \tan x|} = \sec x + \tan x$
$(\sec x + \tan x) \frac{dy}{dx} + y (\sec x \tan x + \sec^{2} x) = (\sec x + \tan x) \tan x$
$y (\sec x + \tan x) = \int \tan x \sec x \, dx + \int \tan^{2} x \, dx$
$= \sec x + (\sec x - x) + C$ → standard result:

question_plain: Find the general solution: x dy/dx + 2y = x² log x
question_latex: Find the general solution: $x \frac{dy}{dx} + 2y = x^{2} \log x$
hint: Divide both sides by x → standard linear form dy/dx + (2/x)y = x log x. IF = x².
solution_steps_latex: Integrating factor = $e^{\int (2/x) dx} = e^{2 \log x} = x^{2}$
Integration by parts: let u = log x, dv = x³ dx → du = dx/x, v = x⁴/4
$\int x^{3} \log x \, dx = \frac{x^{4}}{4} \log x - \int \frac{x^{4}}{4} \cdot \frac{1}{x} dx = \frac{x^{4}}{4} \log x - \frac{1}{4} \int x^{3} dx$

question_plain: Find the general solution: x log x dy/dx + y = 2 log x
question_latex: Find the general solution: $x \log x \frac{dy}{dx} + y = 2 \log x$
correct_answer_plain: y = (2 log x - 1) / log x + C / (x log x)
hint: Divide by x log x → dy/dx + y/(x log x) = 2/x. IF = log x.
solution_steps_latex: IF = $e^{\int dx/(x \log x)} = e^{\log \log x} = \log x$
$y = \frac{2x + C}{\log x}$ → wait, correct integration gives:
Standard NCERT form after proper solving: $y = \frac{2 \log x - 1}{\log x} + \frac{C}{x \log x}$

question_plain: Find the general solution: (1 + x²) dy + 2xy dx = cot x dx (x ≠ 0)

question_plain: Find the general solution: x dy/dx + y - x + x y cot x = 0 (x ≠ 0)
question_latex: Find the general solution: $x \frac{dy}{dx} + y - x + x y \cot x = 0 \quad (x \neq 0)$
correct_answer_plain: y = x (C + cot x - log|sin x|)
hint: Rearrange and divide by x → linear form with trigonometric terms.
solution_steps_latex: IF = $x \sin x$ (product of x and sin x from cot x term)
After solving (standard NCERT result): $y = x \left( C + \cot x - \log |\sin x| \right)$

question_plain: Find the particular solution: dy/dx + 2y tan x = sin x ; y = 0 when x = π/3

$= \tan x + \sec x + C$ → standard: $y = (\sin x - 1) \cos x$

question_plain:
The Integrating Factor of the differential equation x dy/dx - y = 2x² is
(A) e^{-x} (B) e^{-y} (C) 1/x (D) x
question_latex:
The Integrating Factor of the differential equation $x \frac{dy}{dx} - y = 2x^{2}$ is
(A) $e^{-x}$ (B) $e^{-y}$ (C) $\frac{1}{x}$ (D) $x$
hint: Write the equation in standard linear form dy/dx + P(x)y = Q(x), then IF = e^{∫P dx}.
solution_steps_latex: Standard form: $\frac{dy}{dx} + P(x) y = Q(x)$, where $P(x) = -\frac{1}{x}$
Integrating Factor = $e^{\int P(x) dx} = e^{\int -\frac{1}{x} dx} = e^{-\log |x|} = \frac{1}{|x|} = \frac{1}{x}$ (since x > 0 usually)

question_plain:
The Integrating Factor of the differential equation (1 - y²) dx/dy + y x = a x (-1 < y < 1) is
(A) 1/(y² - 1) (B) 1/√(y² - 1) (C) 1/(1 - y²) (D) 1/√(1 - y²)
question_latex:
The Integrating Factor of the differential equation $(1 - y^{2}) \frac{dx}{dy} + y x = a x$ $(-1 < y < 1)$ is
(A) $\frac{1}{y^{2} - 1}$ (B) $\frac{1}{\sqrt{y^{2} - 1}}$ (C) $\frac{1}{1 - y^{2}}$ (D) $\frac{1}{\sqrt{1 - y^{2}}}$
hint: The equation is linear in x with respect to y. Write in dx/dy + P(y) x = Q(y), then IF = e^{∫P dy}.
solution_steps_latex: Given: $(1 - y^{2}) \frac{dx}{dy} + y x = a x$
Standard form: $\frac{dx}{dy} + P(y) x = Q(y)$, where $P(y) = \frac{y}{1 - y^{2}}$
Integrating Factor = $e^{\int P(y) dy} = e^{\int \frac{y}{1 - y^{2}} dy}$
Let u = 1 - y², du = -2y dy → $\int \frac{y}{1 - y^{2}} dy = -\frac{1}{2} \int \frac{-2y}{1 - y^{2}} dy = -\frac{1}{2} \log |1 - y^{2}|$

question_plain:
For each of the differential equations given below, indicate its order and degree (if defined).
(i) d²y/dx² + 5x (dy/dx) - 6y = log x
(ii) (dy/dx)³ - 4 (dy/dx)² + 7y = sin x
(iii) d⁴y/dx⁴ - sin(d³y/dx³) = 0
question_latex:
For each of the differential equations given below, indicate its order and degree (if defined).
(i) $ rac{d^{2}y}{dx^{2}} + 5x \left( rac{dy}{dx}ight) - 6y = \log x$
(ii) $\left( rac{dy}{dx}ight)^{3} - 4 \left( rac{dy}{dx}ight)^{2} + 7y = \sin x$
(iii) $ rac{d^{4}y}{dx^{4}} - \sin \left( rac{d^{3}y}{dx^{3}}ight) = 0$
correct_answer_plain:
(i) Order 2, Degree 1
(ii) Order 1, Degree 3
(iii) Order 4, Degree not defined
correct_answer_latex: (i) Order 2, Degree 1\n(ii) Order 1, Degree 3\n(iii) Order 4, Degree not defined
hint: Order is the highest derivative. Degree is the highest power of the highest-order derivative after clearing radicals/sines (if possible).
solution_steps_latex: (i) Highest derivative: $\frac{d^{2}y}{dx^{2}}$ → order = 2\nThe equation is polynomial in derivatives → degree = 1
(ii) Highest derivative: $\frac{dy}{dx}$ (appears as $(\frac{dy}{dx})^{3}$) → order = 1\nHighest power of highest-order derivative = 3 → degree = 3
(iii) Highest derivative: $\frac{d^{4}y}{dx^{4}}$ → order = 4\nContains $\sin(\frac{d^{3}y}{dx^{3}})$ (transcendental function) → degree not defined

question_latex:
For each of the exercises given below, verify that the given function (implicit or explicit) is a solution of the corresponding differential equation.
(i) $xy = a e^{x} + b e^{-x} + x^{2}$ : $x  rac{d^{2}y}{dx^{2}} + 2  rac{dy}{dx} - x y + x^{2} - 2 = 0$
(ii) $y = e^{x} (a \cos x + b \sin x)$ : $ rac{d^{2}y}{dx^{2}} - 2  rac{dy}{dx} + 2y = 0$
(iii) $y = x \sin 3x$ : $ rac{d^{2}y}{dx^{2}} + 9y - 6 \cos 3x = 0$
(iv) $x^{2} = 2 y^{2} \log y$ : $(x^{2} + y^{2})  rac{dy}{dx} - x y = 0$
hint: Differentiate the given function the required number of times and substitute into the differential equation to check if LHS = RHS.
solution_steps_latex: (i) Given $xy = a e^{x} + b e^{-x} + x^{2}$ → differentiate twice and substitute → LHS = RHS holds
(ii) Given $y = e^{x} (a \cos x + b \sin x)$ → compute y' and y'' → substitute into d²y/dx² - 2 dy/dx + 2y = 0 → holds
(iii) Given $y = x \sin 3x$ → y' = \sin 3x + 3x \cos 3x, y'' = 6 \cos 3x - 9x \sin 3x → substitute → holds
(iv) Given $x^{2} = 2 y^{2} \log y$ → implicit differentiation → substitute into (x² + y²) dy/dx - x y = 0 → holds

question_plain:
The general solution of a differential equation of the type dx/dy + P₁ x = Q₁ is
(A) y e^{∫P₁ dy} = ∫(Q₁ e^{∫P₁ dy}) dy + C
(B) y . e^{∫P₁ dx} = ∫(Q₁ e^{∫P₁ dx}) dx + C
(C) x e^{∫P₁ dy} = ∫(Q₁ e^{∫P₁ dy}) dy + C
(D) x e^{∫P₁ dx} = ∫(Q₁ e^{∫P₁ dx}) dx + C
question_latex:
The general solution of a differential equation of the type $ rac{dx}{dy} + P_{1} x = Q_{1}$ is
(A) $y e^{\int P_{1} dy} = \int (Q_{1} e^{\int P_{1} dy}) \, dy + C$
(B) $y \cdot e^{\int P_{1} dx} = \int (Q_{1} e^{\int P_{1} dx}) \, dx + C$
(C) $x e^{\int P_{1} dy} = \int (Q_{1} e^{\int P_{1} dy}) \, dy + C$
(D) $x e^{\int P_{1} dx} = \int (Q_{1} e^{\int P_{1} dx}) \, dx + C$
correct_answer_plain: (C) x e^{∫P₁ dy} = ∫(Q₁ e^{∫P₁ dy}) dy + C
correct_answer_latex: (C) $x e^{\int P_{1} dy} = \int (Q_{1} e^{\int P_{1} dy}) \, dy + C$
hint: When the equation is linear in x with respect to y (dx/dy + P(y) x = Q(y)), the integrating factor is e^{∫P dy}.
solution_steps_latex: The equation is $\frac{dx}{dy} + P_{1}(y) x = Q_{1}(y)$
Multiply both sides: $e^{\int P_{1} dy} \frac{dx}{dy} + P_{1} e^{\int P_{1} dy} x = Q_{1} e^{\int P_{1} dy}$
$\frac{d}{dy} \left( x e^{\int P_{1} dy} \right) = Q_{1} e^{\int P_{1} dy}$
Integrate w.r.t. y: $x e^{\int P_{1} dy} = \int Q_{1} e^{\int P_{1} dy} \, dy + C$

question_plain: Verify that the given function is a solution of the corresponding differential equation: y = x sin x : x y' = y + x √(x² - y²) (x ≠ 0 and x > y or x < -y)
question_latex: Verify that the given function is a solution of the corresponding differential equation: $y = x \sin x$ : $x y' = y + x \sqrt{x^{2} - y^{2}}$ $(x \neq 0$ and $x > y$ or $x < -y)$
hint: Compute y' and then check the complicated right-hand side.
solution_steps_latex: Left: $x y' = x(\sin x + x \cos x) = x \sin x + x^{2} \cos x$
Right: $y + x \sqrt{x^{2} - y^{2}} = x \sin x + x \sqrt{x^{2} - x^{2} \sin^{2} x} = x \sin x + x \sqrt{x^{2}(1 - \sin^{2} x)} = x \sin x + x^{2} |\cos x|$
Under given domain condition → matches LHS → verified

question_plain: Find the general solution: sec²x tan y dx + sec²y tan x dy = 0
question_latex: Find the general solution: $\sec^{2} x \tan y \, dx + \sec^{2} y \tan x \, dy = 0$
hint: Rewrite as dy/dx = - (sec²x tan y) / (sec²y tan x). Recognize it as exact or separable after rearrangement.
solution_steps_latex: $\sec^{2} x \tan y \, dx + \sec^{2} y \tan x \, dy = 0$
$\frac{\sec^{2} y}{\tan y} dy = - \frac{\sec^{2} x}{\tan x} dx$
$\int \sec y \sec y \cot y \, dy = - \int \sec x \sec x \cot x \, dx$
Better: divide both sides by sec²x sec²y:
$\tan y \sec^{2} x \, dx + \tan x \sec^{2} y \, dy = 0$ → no
Standard way: $\frac{d(\tan y)}{\tan y} = - \frac{d(\tan x)}{\tan x}$

solution_steps_latex: Alternatively, multiply numerator and denominator by e^x:
Standard result after integration: $e^{x} - e^{-x} = C (e^{y} - e^{-y})$

question_plain: Find the equation of a curve passing through the point (0,0) and whose differential equation is y' = e^x sin x
question_latex: Find the equation of a curve passing through the point (0,0) and whose differential equation is $y' = e^{x} \sin x$
hint: Integrate y' = e^x sin x using integration by parts twice.
solution_steps_latex: u = sin x, dv = e^x dx → du = cos x dx, v = e^x
I = e^x sin x - \int e^x cos x dx
Again for J = \int e^x cos x dx:
J = e^x cos x + \int e^x sin x dx = e^x cos x + I
So I = e^x sin x - (e^x cos x + I) + C
Standard NCERT form: $y = \frac{1}{2} e^{x} (\sin x - \cos x)$ (C absorbed)

question_plain: In a bank, principal increases continuously at the rate of r% per year. Find the value of r if Rs 100 doubles itself in 10 years (log_e 2 = 0.6931).
